Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to send one frame and is delivered to all devices on the LAN. It is used when a frame needs to be sent to all devices within the broadcast domain. A multicast address is used to send one frame and is delivered to a specific group of devices on the LAN. It is used when a frame needs to be sent to a select group of devices. IP addresses and MAC addresses are not specifically related to sending one frame to multiple devices. An IP address is used for network layer addressing, and a MAC address is a unique identifier for network interfaces. Unicast address refers to sending one frame to a single device.

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: The correct option is a. CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is a set of rules used in Ethernet networks to manage how devices respond when they detect that two devices are trying to transmit data at the same time, causing a collision. CSMA/CD helps in detecting collisions and then taking appropriate actions to retransmit the data.

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. This standard specifies Gigabit Ethernet operation over Category 5e or better twisted-pair cable.

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer is used to allow devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 7-octet (56-bit) pattern of alternating 1s and 0s, which helps the receiving devices synchronize their clocks with the incoming data stream.

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: The correct answer is b. The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. The default gateway serves as the exit point from the host's subnet to reach destinations in other subnets.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) resides in the Application layer of the TCP/IP model. It is responsible for sending and receiving email.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) resides in the Transport layer of the TCP/IP model. It provides reliable, connection-oriented communication between devices.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) both reside in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer. TCP provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of a stream of packets on the internet, while IP is responsible for routing packets across network boundaries.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet resides in the Data Link layer of the TCP/IP Architecture. It is responsible for the physical transmission of data between network devices.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: The correct protocol used from PC1 to learn information from another device on the same network is ARP (Address Resolution Protocol). ARP is used to map a known IP address to a MAC address on a local network. When a device needs to communicate with another device on the same network, it uses ARP to discover the MAC address associated with the IP address of the destination device.

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: A straight-through cable is used to connect unlike devices, where the transmit pins on one end are connected to the receive pins on the other end. For the pairs mentioned, a straight-through cable is needed for connecting a Router and a PC as they are unlike devices (one is a networking device and the other an end device). Similarly, a straight-through cable is required for connecting a Hub and a Switch as they are also unlike devices.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: Ethernet and PPP are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols. Ethernet is a widely used LAN technology that operates at the data-link layer, providing communication within the same network. PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) is used to establish a direct connection between two nodes and is also a data-link layer protocol.

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: A and B are correct. Routing protocols are responsible for learning routes from neighboring routers and populating the routing table with this information (statement a). They also advertise known routes to neighboring routers to share routing information (statement b). Learning routes for directly connected subnets (statement c) is a function of the router itself, not specifically a routing protocol. Forwarding IP packets based on destination IP address (statement d) is a function of the routing table and the forwarding process, not the routing protocol.

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is TRUE. When a user types in a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, the computer needs to resolve this hostname to an IP address to communicate with the web server. This resolution process is done through the Domain Name System (DNS), which translates domain names to IP addresses.

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to all devices on a specific network segment. When a device sends data to the broadcast address, it reaches all devices within that network.

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: The correct answer is UDP (User Datagram Protocol). TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol) are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols. While HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols, UDP is a transport layer protocol.

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors. It is a part of the Ethernet frame used to check the integrity of the received frame. The FCS is a CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) value that is calculated by the sending device and added to the frame. The receiving device performs the same calculation and compares its result to the FCS; if they match, the frame is considered error-free.
